awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards Millimeter Wave Communications for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
With the proliferation of bandwidth hungry mobile devices, dense deployments of users, and the proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, broadband spectrum needs have been continuously increasing in recent years. The use of the millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency bands is seen as a major way to address this spectrum crunch problem since large amounts of licensed and unlicensed bandwidths are available at these frequencies, leading to new standards being developed for 5G cellular and Wi-Fi using mmWave. In parallel, there have been unprecedented recent advances in commercial unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technologies, which has resulted in their adoption in a wide range of applications, such as disaster relief, agricultural monitoring, wireless connectivity in rural areas, and hotspot connectivity for major sporting events. The proposed research in this project aims to study the foundations of mmWave communications in UAVs in a systematic manner using notions from wireless networks, communication theory, optimization theory, and software defined radios (SDRs), starting from channel sounding and characterization. The data collected from this project will be made public and disseminated via the 5G Millimeter Wave Channel Modeling Alliance. The project will train both graduate students and undergraduate students across multiple institutions in an emerging area of national interest.

A key challenge in any mmWave communication is that beamforming needs to be used in order to overcome the path loss. The use of mmWave on UAVs poses additional challenges and benefits. The challenges are primarily due to limited battery life and weight carrying capability of UAVs and the benefits accrue from the use of: 1) large bandwidth; 2) ability to implement 3D beamforming enabling improved spatial reuse; and 3) harnessing the UAV mobility to perform dynamic UAV clustering and interference management. The goal of this project is to address these fundamental challenges via a unique research collaboration focused on developing the next-generation of analytical and experimental tools for designing, modeling, optimizing, and testing mmWave UAV networks. Specific areas of study will include: (i) novel precoder designs for mmWave UAVs taking into account realistic propagation characteristics derived from channel sounding experiments; (ii) equalizer design for mmWave UAVs that trade-off beamwidth against equalizer structure; (iii) multiple access design for mmWave UAVs: code division and time division multiple access techniques will be revisited for mmWave UAV communications, for serving users that are accessed by the same transmitter beam; and (iv) optimal UAV placement for multi-hop wireless backhaul by investigating the use of UAVs as flying relays.

por.por_cntn:
The general results of our research are characterization of commercially deployed 5G mmWave signals, degradation of the performance of 5G devices based on CPU and skin temperature, and the impacts of out-of-band interference between adjacent 5G bands.

We initially performed measurements of 5G mmWave commercially deployed systems.  This includes developing a measurement methodology and mobile application for measuring 5G mmWave signals.  This allowed us to characterize 5G mmWave performance in dense urban environments.  These were measurement campaigns of the three major commercial 5G mmWave service providers (AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon) in Chicago and Miami. We also measured throughput performance of various Advanced 4G/LTE technologies across various frequency bands.  We then compared these performances to the 5G mmWave measurements that we collected and compiled.  Further, we measured and compiled 5G mmWave performance as a function of human body blockage, distance, and number of devices connected to the base station.   Finally, the above measurements were taken utilizing mobile applications on smartphones.  This provides the opportunity in the future for more crowd sourced measurements within dense urban environments.  This work was presented at the ACM WinTECH 2021 conference on April 1st, 2022 in New Orleans.

We also performed detailed measurements and analyses in two cities of the impact of both CPU and skin temperature (as measured by the device) on the device throughput and its ability to sustain high performance over a period of time (several minutes).  We demonstrated the adaptation of the device to changing thermal conditions from initial to sustained downloading as device temperature rises.  This adaptation includes a reduction in component carriers and eventually a switch to LTE from 5G, thus degrading throughput.  We identify that these adaptations are due to thermal issues and device protection, as indicated by link layer signaling.  This work was presented at the IEEE ComSoc International Communications Quality and Reliability Workshop (IEEE CQR) on September 13th, 2022 in Arlington, VA.

Our most recent work focuses on the C-Band spectrum and its interference on the adjacent Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) band and vice versa.  We identied an outdoor 5G C-Band dployment by Verizon in Chicago.  Additionally we deployed a private 4G CBRS Base Station indoors.  We also had two devices, CBRS and C-Band that we connected to each of the deployment (services).  Based on our measurements we were able to characterize the downlink throughput reduction on both the CBRS and C-Band clients on their respective devices.  Our analysis shows a downlink throughput reduction of nearly ~20% on the 4G CBRS client.  We also found ~48% reduction on the 5G C-Band client. Using a spectrum analyzer, we further confirmed the OOB interference, which was shown by the higher spectrum power received by each channel when the other adjacent channel is used for transmission. Lastly, we implemented and demonstrated the effect of MicroSlicing technology at the CBRS BS to improve ping latency performance under heavy downlink traffic load and adjacent channel coexistence.  This work will be presented at the IEEE International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications 5-8 September 2023 in Toronto, Canada.
